oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Woman's angle on France - via the WACs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Article about the experience of women in the Women's Army Corps stationed in France in 1944. According to the article, thirty WACs were sent to England on D-Day for duty in France. The article discusses women's struggles with language barriers, bathing and laundry.

Because of the volume of soldiers needed on the front lines during World War II, the United States government allowed women to fill non-combatant positions in the military in order to release as many men as possible for fighting. Every branch of the military incorporated women into their ranks in some fashion.Stars and Stripes was a daily periodical published by the U.S. Armed Forces for military personnel stationed in the European Theater of Operations. The Women's Army Corps was the only women's military branch, aside from the Army and Navy Nurse Corps, to station women outside of the U.S. or U.S. controlled territories.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Chapmond, Selma L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War 1939-1945; Women and the military; United States-- Armed Forces--Women's Reserves; United States-- Armed Forces-- Women
Women; Military life; Military personnel;
